Political uncertainty has played a part in weaker UK growth, as has the reversal of stockpiling in Q1. As
well as the fall in stocks and imports, the weakness in export volumes may partly reflect European
customers diverting their supply chains away from the UK to prevent possible disruption in a 'no deal'
Brexit scenario. Some manufacturing companies have alluded to this in their responses to the PMI survey
in recent months. Meanwhile, weak business investment likely reflects the political uncertainty.
But it is also worth keeping in mind that growth slowed globally in Q2, relative to a strong Q1 - and
particularly in Europe. In the Eurozone GDP, growth slowed to 0.2% q-o-q from 0.5% in Q1, and we
expect the German economy to have contracted by 0.2% q-o-q (the data will be released next week). So,
this is not just a Brexit story, either.
Still, the weakness in the UK's all-important service sector is worrying. As James Pomeroy points out in
Manufacturing Malaise, (9 August 2019), the global story thus far has largely affected the manufacturing
sector, not the service sector. So for the latter to be looking so weak in the UK is worrying.
In terms of UK growth from here, we expect something of the pattern from H1 to be repeated:
stockpiling will likely lift growth in Q3 (our forecast is 0.3% q-o-q) ahead of the new 31 October Brexit
date, followed by an unwind in Q4. The scale of the slowdown in Q4 will depend on the terms of the
UK's exit from the EU. Assuming the country avoids a 'no deal' Brexit, we forecast a final quarter print
of 0.1% q-o-q. But a disruptive 'no deal' Brexit could mean another negative print. We would expect the
UK to enter recession in that scenario

The timing of the original Article 50 deadline — and the response of firms to potential disruption — imparted considerable volatility to the path of GDP before and after 29 March. BE11:15am

MAIN POINTS:
1. The monthly data show that GDP was flat in June, with sequential growth in April and May each revised down by 0.1pp. Within the output breakdown available at a monthly frequency, the services sector stagnated, while manufacturing and construction both contracted on the month (by 0.2% and 0.7% respectively).
2. The quarterly data imply that GDP contracted by 0.2%qoq in Q2, after growth of 0.5%qoq in Q1. The output breakdown revealed that the services sector was the only positive contributor to growth (0.08pt). Industrial production detracted 0.19pt from quarter-on-quarter GDP growth, while construction detracted 0.08pt. The expenditure breakdown indicated a notable reduction in imports (after a sharp Brexit-induced expansion in Q1) and a sharp decline in inventories (following four consecutive quarters of accumulation). More fundamentally, growth in business investment fell back into negative territory in Q2 (-0.5%) after a transient improvement in Q1 (+0.4%).

11:16 am
BE11:16am

3. The GDP data for Q1 and Q2 should be interpreted in conjunction, not least because the timing of the original (29 March) Article 50 deadline prompted manufacturers to bring forward production from Q2 to Q1 in order to avoid potential Brexit-induced disruption. Several car manufacturers also brought forward their annual shutdowns from August to April as part of Brexit contingency plans; the latest inventories data suggest that Brexit-related stockpiling detracted from growth in Q2, having boosted growth in Q1. On net, the level of UK GDP rose by 0.30% through the first six months of 2019: down from 0.91% through the last six months of 2018.

o It’s very scary how a “no deal Brexit” has become normalised in the public debate. It’s becoming more like no deal Brexit or revoke as the two options. We’re not there yet, but it’s become a debate of ideologies rather than practical solutions. This evolving trend is why no deal has become more of a base case for folks in the market rather than an outside tail risk. Pound lower as a result.

o EU talks are going nowhere: Its important, the two ways to avoid a no deal are a deal with the EU or revoking article 50. Having little progress in talks by September increases the risk of an election being held on a mandate for “no deal” platform.

o Parliament returning from recess is a big deal: We’ve been in a news vacuum with parliament in recess. When they return (3 Sep) expect an early vote of no confidence in the new Prime Minister and his government to be called for the following day. It’s a difficult endeavour to predict the direction of GBP on such a headline. But overall an election will only serve to make investing in the UK for that campaign period more difficult and the currency will depreciate as a result. But it’s not a one way consensus on this! As some may deem an election likely to reduce hard Brexit risks and not concentrate on the Corbyn risk at that stage. Then there is the matter of the election timing, before or after a hard Brexit.

§ I’ve not gotten stuck into the weeds of the argument over a VONC leading to Boris choosing an election date after 31 October. Because even constitutional law experts disagree over what the PM can and can’t do. If an election were pencilled in for early Nov, whilst the hardliners would be very satisfied, I’m not sure the Conservative party as a whole would be happy with such manoeuvres. Business and party backers would also be up in arms. It seems to be more of a communication agenda to put off wavering MPs from backing such a move in the first day of parliament (link). That’s the optimist in me, but it’s a subject I’ll get stuck into more in coming weeks. Golden rule: If a strategy requires the Queen to make a political decision…it’s not much of a strategy. Also if there is a majority against a no deal & a majority in favour of a vote of no confidence, then there probably is a majority that would amend FTPA and other legislation to avoid this dire scenario of an election campaign leading to hard Brexit by design.

o It will depend on the circumstances of the election: Markets trade on narratives. If the election is held as a choice between a labour led government or a no deal Brexit Conservative/Brexit combination it’s hard to see the light at the end of the tunnel for the pound. Unless the Lib Dems keep making new ground...Making a forecast of the outcome of the next election is a fool’s errand, the polls are more volatile than ever before! Hence why it’s difficult to see GBP rally on an election headline given the uncertainty.

The UK Economy:

o Global backdrop: We are in the midst of a global slowdown that was in full effect before the increased US/China trade tensions which will just serve to make things worse. If this carries on without stimulus from governments and central banks, then it won’t be long until recession risks are spoken much more openly about.

o UK Growth: The global story is a big problem for the UK given the timing with Brexit. We saw the world enter a huge upswing around the time of the 2016 referendum result. Global trade picked up in a way that it was difficult for the UK to be completely left out and we avoided a recession. But make no mistake, the UK growth underperformed peers and would have been worse without the devaluation of the pound that provided a cushion. But you can’t shrink to success, if the pound were to keep on falling at this rate, the inflation potential would bite into consumers’ pockets with the cost of energy and goods likely to rise. Good for UK exports but would be a large adjustment for consumers that is not clear would lead to long term success.

§ If anything the UK’s growth score is below trend, suggesting the need for monetary easing/fiscal stimulus.

o Inflation: Currently at the BOE’s target of 2.0%. Likely to go down over the next few months into October, as the UK has experienced slower growth than forecasted. But then higher in the long run after Brexit. The BOE deems a 10% fall in the pound equates to 0.8% added to headline inflation. We’ve witness a 7% fall in the pound since the end of March so these are numbers that are not too far away from being tested.

o BOE: Very unlikely to do anything until Brexit is out of the way, deal or no deal. If we have a deal or positive outcome. They will raise rates at a pace of once a year. But just as that happens they could be witnessing a global slowdown and recession.

ow far can the pound fall on a no deal Brexit? GBP has fallen a lot already. So what is the true “hard Brexit” level? We define GBP’s “hard Brexit equilibrium” as the level where the current account would start heading into balance or at least become more manageable in a no-deal scenario such as 2% of GDP. The answer is roughly the same as it was in 2016: the pound would fall somewhere to the region of 1.14-1.18 in GBP/USD and 0.95-0.98 in EUR/GBP.

§ But what is the worst case scenario? It is not completely inconceivable that neither side takes the right mitigating steps for trade and financial services in a no-deal outcome. If so then we find GBP/USD at 1.01 to 1.05 or EUR/GBP at 1.03-1.06 could be the new level to bear in mind.

BE11:24am

AMD’s EPYC launch event yesterday afternoon highlighted EPYC 2’s disruptive performance advantage (1.8-2x performance advantage and 25-50% lower TCO) but also an ecosystem of OEMs, partners, and customers. AMD is still committed to a double-digit server share by early 2020 at the latest. Announced customers included many of the same cloud customers as with Epyc 1 (AWS, MSFT etc) but it always takes time for those instances to be adopted by an end customer to drive volume. AMD did have Twitter on stage who plans to have EPYC deployed this year and the “one more thing” was Google who signaled they would use EPYC 2 in the cloud but also internally. OEMs including Dell, HP, Cray, Lenovo all signaled products available with EPYC 2. Still not a straight line to 10%+ share but clearly a good sign of early traction.

BE11:24am

rom an architecture perspective, AMD’s use of 7nm is the headline (and rightly so as it delivers a 50% power reduction) but we would also highlight the chiplet design (Intel likely moves to multi-chip at 7nm), higher core counts (64 vs Intel's 56 max), greater IO across product ranges (Intel limits single socket to force dual socket use) and use of PCI 4 (Intel not until Ice Lake). Third party benchmarks should trickle out over the next few weeks but AMD showed multiple benchmarks where it’s high-end was 80-100% better than Intel’s high-end. AMD also showed a 2-4x TCO advantage given the higher cores per chip, use of single socket vs dual, and lower price points. AMD even went as far as to say that it’s single socket EPYC could outperform Intel’s entire dual socket lineup

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Without all of the data it’s hard to fully understand if the value proposition is really this good but Intel clearly has left the door open with its 10nm struggle. The comparisons were vs Intel Cascade Lake and everything that have heard from the channel has shown little customer interest in that platform let alone Cooper Lake in 2020. Ice Lake (10nm) was recently delayed into 2H20 and everything we have seen so far from the notebook launch suggests there are still problems with this 10nm process. Regardless, if you follow AMD’s cadence of a new platform every 4-5 months, process technology is effectively a wash as you would get Milan (7+ or more likely 6nm) in 2H20 and Genoa (5nm) in early 2022 vs Intel at 10nm (compares to TSMC 7nm) 2H20 and 7nm in 2022. So the question is if AMD really did close the gap on IPC (instructions per cycle) from the 20% deficit last generation. The high-end data didn’t show this but AMD indicated that they believe they are close to parity in the important mid-range.

Net net, we believe AMD delivered what they needed to do. Time will tell just how Intel will respond (pricing or share) and we do understand that share gains happen slowly but we maintain our UW on Intel as we believe this is early days of what we see as a long drawn out battle.

All in, we walk away from the event with increased confidence in AMD’s ability to gain share in the server CPU market. An increase in competition could certainly impact the slope of the ASP and therefore margin trajectory, but we believe a) Intel is unlikely to cut price to the point where it jeopardizes its margin goals (especially given management’s intense focus on improving operating margins), and b) even if Intel were to compete on price, we believe marginal cuts would have minimal impact on the market share balance as the long-term benefits from having choice in the market likely outweigh the near-term benefits from price reductions.
